                     Breadcrumbs                                  Home                                               Academics                                               Faculty                                               Mohammed Qasaimeh                                                          Mohammed Qasaimeh                                                                             Mohammed Qasaimeh, Assistant Professor of Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering, NYUAD                                                      Mohammed Qasaimeh                  Assistant Professor of Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering                                Affiliation: NYU Abu Dhabi                                                 Biography      B.S. Jordan University of Science and Technology; M.A.Sc. Concordia University; Ph.D. McGill University   Mohammad directs the Advanced Microfluidics and Microdevices Laboratory (AMMLab) at NYU Abu Dhabi, and his current research interests include developing microfluidic and MEMS devices for biomedical applications and point of care diagnostics. During his PhD work, he received several prestigious fellowships and awards including the NSERC Postdoctoral Fellowship, the Alexander Graham Bell Graduate Scholarship (CGSD3), and the FQRNT Students-Researchers Stars Award. His research has been published in several peer-reviewed journals including Nature Communications, Lab on a Chip, and Biomedical Microdevies.   Mohammad Qasaimeh joined NYUAD from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology where he served as a Postdoctoral Research Associate. Prior to that, he served as a Research Assistant at McGill University and as a Research Fellow at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute and Harvard Medical School.                                                                The Advanced Microfluidics and Microdevices Laboratory (AMMLab)                 The AMMLab is working with various aspects of miniaturization and integration in biology, life sciences, and medicine, which includes the conception, engineering and utilization of novel micro and nanotechnologies to manipulate, stimulate, and study biological objects. The AMMLab mainly develop microfluidic and MEMS-based devices for applications in biology and life sciences. Mohammed Qasaimeh, Assistant Professor of Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering, NYUAD                                                      Mohammed Qasaimeh                  Assistant Professor of Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering                                Affiliation: NYU Abu Dhabi                                                 Biography      B.S. Jordan University of Science and Technology; M.A.Sc. Concordia University; Ph.D. McGill University   Mohammad directs the Advanced Microfluidics and Microdevices Laboratory (AMMLab) at NYU Abu Dhabi, and his current research interests include developing microfluidic and MEMS devices for biomedical applications and point of care diagnostics. During his PhD work, he received several prestigious fellowships and awards including the NSERC Postdoctoral Fellowship, the Alexander Graham Bell Graduate Scholarship (CGSD3), and the FQRNT Students-Researchers Stars Award. His research has been published in several peer-reviewed journals including Nature Communications, Lab on a Chip, and Biomedical Microdevies.   Mohammad Qasaimeh joined NYUAD from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology where he served as a Postdoctoral Research Associate. Prior to that, he served as a Research Assistant at McGill University and as a Research Fellow at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute and Harvard Medical School.                                                                The Advanced Microfluidics and Microdevices Laboratory (AMMLab)                 The AMMLab is working with various aspects of miniaturization and integration in biology, life sciences, and medicine, which includes the conception, engineering and utilization of novel micro and nanotechnologies to manipulate, stimulate, and study biological objects. The AMMLab mainly develop microfluidic and MEMS-based devices for applications in biology and life sciences. Research Team | AMMLab                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             AMMLab Home   Research Team   Research   Publications   Lab Resources   Contact Us   Join US   News   Library                                                                        Research Team          Mohammad A. Qasaimeh, PhD   Assistant Professor of Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering, NYU Abu Dhabi   Principal Investigator of the AMMLab, NYU Abu Dhabi   Dr. Mohammad Qasaimeh directs the Advanced Microfluidics and Microdevices Laboratory (AMMLab), and his current research interests include developing microfluidic and MEMS devices for biomedical applications and point of care diagnostics. During his PhD work, he received several prestigious fellowships and awards including the NSERC Postdoctoral Fellowship, the Alexander Graham Bell Graduate Scholarship (CGSD3), and the FQRNT Students-Researchers Stars Award. His research has been published in several peer-reviewed journals including Nature Communications, Lab on a Chip, and Biomedical Microdevies. Mohammad joined NYUAD from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology where he served as a Postdoctoral Research Associate. Prior to that, he served as a Research Assistant at McGill University and as a Research Fellow at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute and Harvard Medical School. Mohammad received his B.S. degree in Mechanical Engineering from Jordan University of Science and Technology; the M.A.Sc degree in Mechanical Engineering from Concordia University; and his Ph.D in Biomedical Engineering from McGill University.   Contact:  mohammad.qasaimeh@nyu.edu   Anoop Menachery, PhD   Research Scientist   Dr. Anoop Menachery is currently a Research Scientist in the AMMLab. He has several years of experience in the fields of AC electrokinetics and microsystems. His expertise lies in the development of microfluidic devices and in the design and execution of technical concepts for device integration. Dr. Menachery has previously worked as a senior engineer at Apocell, where he was involved in the development, validation and commercialization of an automated product to isolate circulating tumor cells from patient blood. He also previously worked as a postdoctoral researcher in the bio-electronics group at the Universities of Glasgow and Edinburgh in the area of microfabrication technologies applied to the detection and isolation of embryonic stem cells and parasites. Dr. Menachery obtained a Master’s degree in Nanotechnology and Microfabrication and a PhD in Electronic Engineering from Bangor University, UK.   Contact:  anoop.menachery@nyu.edu   Jordi Vila-Planas, PhD   Postdoctoral Research Associate   Dr. Jordi Vila-Planas joined the AMMLab as a Postdoctoral Research Associate. Jordi received his bachelor degree in physics from Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona, and his master degree in Photonics from Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya. Before joining the AMMLab, Jordi was a graduate student in the Centre Nacional de Microelectrònica, CNM-IMB, CSIC, and completed his Ph.D. dissertation on PDMS-based optofluidic systems in September 2014. Jordi’s research of interest is at the intersection of microfluidics and photonics, and its applications in biological and life sciences.   Contact:  jvp2@nyu.edu   Mohammed Nesro, M.Sc   Research Assistant   Before joining the AMMLab as a research assistant, Mohammed Nesro was a graduate student and a research assistant at Masdar Institute of Science and Technology (MIST), Abu Dhabi, UAE. Nesro received his master degree in Microsystems Engineering from MIST, and his Bachelor degree in Electrical and Computer Engineering from Addis Ababa University, Ethiopia. His master thesis and research focused on CAD modeling for solid-state lithium-ion microbatteries. Nesro received several scholarships and awards during his educations, including the recent “Best Master Thesis Award 2014 from Masdar Institute”. His current research interests include designing, modeling, and characterizing microdevices for life science and medical applications.   Contact:  msn303@nyu.edu                                                  Recent News                 April 1, 2015: Our recent paper is highlighted in the ScienceDaily news.                      April 1, 2015: Our collaborative work with IRCM and McGill University is now published in the prestigious journal PLOS Biology.                      April 1, 2015: Prof. Qasaimeh will be delivering a talk at the Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department Seminar Series, NYU School of Engineering, in April 6th 2015.                      March 25, 2015: Prof. Qasaimeh with NYUAD students “Engineers for Social Impact” are spending a week in Sri Lanka working with “Habitat for Humanity” to help people in building houses for their families                      March 15, 2015: Congratulations to Mohammed Nesro for receiving the prestigious Global PhD Fellowship from NYUAD.                      March 08,2015: We received our conductivity bench-top meter kit( Star® A212) from Thermo Scientific Orion®                                                                   Copy Right by AMMLab @NYUAD               AMMLab Home   Research Team   Research   Publications   Lab Resources   Contact Us   Join US   News   Library
